generalintro.genintrotext: Goal, structure of the course, etc.

unit.title: Introductions, Lang-learning, Family, Speaking the Language

lesson.title: Introductions
lesson.designnote: This lesson starts learners out in the language with the main ways they can describe themselves and their relations: their name, their parents, and where they come from, where they live, and where they work. Being about to name their parents (and where they come from) right off is a particularly important part of self-introduction for learners, since this allows older speakers from their community to place them among the people they know.

dialog.note: Alternative: - So'sep Nuel teluisi. My name is Joseph Noel.

line.english: My father is also from Listuguj.

lesson.title: Coping: how to do your language-learning IN the language
lesson.designnote: This particular lesson is offered right from the start, because it is most effective for learners to learn the language THROUGH the language. By giving them the crucial phrases for this early on, we aim to encourage doing this as much as possible from the getgo, instead of dropping back to English. Learners of course naturally drop back to English, but so do speakers, since it is the language they have used with non-speakers for years. A successful learner has to overcome not only their own lifelong habits of using English, but also has to find polite, respectful ways of turning the conversation from English back to Mi'gmaq wherever reasonably possible. These phrases are one of the key ways they can do this.
lesson.note: @20120731-JV-2redux.wav is the complete and revised version of all of this section. There is also @20120723-JW-RM-1thru25.wav@0:39.5-1:54, as an early draft that would need a redo @0:44, but is otherwise good for voice variation. Note also that there are revised versions of the "fill in the blank" forms, as actual blank-fillers are much better.
lesson.explnote: When you learn a new language, you want to stay speaking in the language as much as possible: the more your mind goes back to English, the slower you will learn. One great trick to keep the conversation solidly in Mig'maq---even when you're not following everything--- is to learn how to ask your major questions ABOUT the langauge IN the language. Here we give the first of a series of phrases that you can use to help stay in the game, no matter what....

line.english: Please speak to me in Native.
Would you be so kind as to talk to me in Native?
Tell me in Native what you are doing.
Tell me in Native what I am doing.

lesson.note: The following two lines are recorded, but should not be used, because the blanks are not easy to make sense of in thevocab. Use instead those with actual English fillers corresponding to the blanks, located at the end of the sound recording.

line.english: I want to know how you say _______.
Where would you use that word?
How would I use that word?

lesson.note: The following two lines are recorded, but should not be used, because the blanks are not easy to make sense of in the audio. Use instead those with actual English fillers corresponding to the blanks, located at the end of the sound recording.

line.english: I want to ask you something. How do you say _______.
I want to ask you how you say _______.
Please tell me something in Native.

lesson.note: The following four lines are the preferred replacements for the "blanks" lines.

line.english: I want to know how you say "I am hungry".
I want to ask you something. How do you say "pail"?
I want to ask you how you say "full moon".

lesson.title: Identifying people
lesson.designnote: This lesson teaches the 'this' and 'that' words of Mi'gmaq, as well as the important question 'who?', and the important /X na Y/ pattern, which acts as an effective equivalent to English 'X is Y, X = Y'. It grounds this in an introduction to part of the four-way system of [older/younger brother/sister] vs. the English two-way system of [brother/sister]. It requires pictures---and would be even better if video---to see the near (ula) and far (ala), and which people the speakers are looking at.
lesson.explnote: There is one special way these basic 'who...?' phrases can help you learn Mi'gmaq by speaking Mi'gmaq. In English we usually ask 'What is that?' to ask someone to tell us what kind of animal we are looking at. But in Mi'gmaq, it is natural to ask "Who is this/that?"---exactly the same as for people. This is one way you can learn new words without having to speak any English at all.

line.english: No, this is my younger brother.
No, that is my younger sister.

lesson.title: Identifying things
lesson.designnote: This lesson introduces the fundamental 'what is this/that?' question so basic to learning a language THROUGH the language. It also reinforces the previously introduced /X na Y/ pattern as an effective equivalent to English 'X is Y, X = Y'. It requires pictures, better if video, to see the near (ula) and far (ala), and which people the speakers are looking at.
lesson.explnote: These phrases are again very good for learning Mi'gmaq by speaking Mi'gmaq. With them, you can point to something (some thing) and learn the word for it without having to speak any English at all.

lesson.title: Identifying siblings overall
lesson.designnote: This lesson introduces plural 'who' (not found directly in English), and presents wijigumjig as an unexplained 'your siblings/brothers and sisters'. An expanded version of this lesson might have an answer using wijigumgig 'my..., those who I...'. This would at least introduce that basic 'I ... them', 'you ... them' pattern. Here however, drawing too much attention to this pattern might overload learners.
lesson.explnote: Wen means 'who?' asking about one person. Wenig means 'who?' asking about more than one person.

line.english: Who are your brothers and sisters?

lesson.title: Identifying siblings by relation
lesson.designnote: Here the 'what is my/your name?' pattern is extended to show the important 's/he...' ending. At the same time, the full four-way system of [older/younger brother/sister] vs. the English two-way system of [brother/sister] is now laid out directly and completely. In the background here is also the use of word order to highlight relative importance of information: the repeated information is first, and then the key new information (the name asked for) comes right before the verb.
lesson.explnote: You have learned the question taluisin? 'what is your name?', and the answer, teluisi 'my name is...'. And here again we see tal- for the question and tel- for the answer. Can you work out who we are talking about when we use this new -t ending? (Hint: it's not you, and it's not me).

line.english: What is your older brother's name?
My older brother's name is Michael.
What is your older sister's name?
My older sister's name is Mary-Ann.
What is your younger brother's name?
My younger brother's name is John.
What is your younger sister's name?
My younger sister's name is Mary.

lesson.title: Identifying uncle, aunt, cousins
lesson.designnote: Three related kinship terms---uncle, aunt, and cousin---are introduced, plus a minimal introduction to 'many' and 'one'. Word order for informational importance/prominence is again demonstrated.

line.migmaq: - Pugwelgig no'gmaq, gatu newte'jit teluisit Poligap.
line.english: I have lots of cousins [lit. 'many are my cousins'], but one is named Polycarpe.

lesson.title: Identifying grandparents
lesson.designnote: Introducing grandparents, reinforcing earlier-introduced patterns.

lesson.title: Identifying deceased relatives
lesson.designnote: Based on previous lessons' kinship terms, we introduce the absentative (= deceased, no longer present) for people/animates: -aq. The P-past -p(n)- and the S-past -s(n)- both naturally come together with the absentative in this context. Not necessary to go into details on this for now with learners. But it is worth being prepared to explain that the P-past is used for a direct perspective on the past (the usual, "I saw it happen myself, or know it for sure"), and the S-past tends to be used for indirect perspective on the past, and in particular, for most questions about the past, as here.
lesson.explnote: The ending -aq added here is mainly used to refer to the deceased. Sometimes you will also hear it used just for someone who has just gone away or even is just asleep (gone off to dreamland). The -sn- and -pn- are both endings used to talk about the past. We will learn more about them later: for now, we can roughly say that the P-past is the main, plain, usual way of talking about the past. The S-past has more special uses: in particular, it is what we usually use to ask questions about the past, like we do here. (You can try thinking about it as the "supposedly" past, since you usually use it when you don't have proof of what happened.

lesson.title: Work/study
lesson.designnote: Reviewing /tami (tett).../ 'where...' pattern, reviewing endings for 'me' and 'you', introducing 'work' and 'study/learn', and briefly, several other important patterns: mu ...-w 'I ... not ...', etl- 'be doing...'
lesson.explnote: You now know enough that you can try to work out on your own the meanings of as many words as possible---by starting with the ones you already know. One hint: who are we talking about when the same word has an -n on the end, and when it doesn't? It will help to think about 'what is your name' and 'my name is' phrases we've learned. Another hint: etl- can be used to show the meaning 'doING', rather than 'did' or 'done'. It can also help emphasize that someone is in the process of doing something in a particular place. Once you've worked out as much as you can on your own, try asking speakers and other learners for help, too!

line.english: I don't work, I'm a student [lit. 'I am studying/learning']

lesson.title: Speaking Native
lesson.designnote: Introducing 'speak ...' verb in the form of 'speak Native'. Pointing out that 'speak Native' is the more common/natural way for Mi'gmaq speaks to convey what would usually be said in English as 'speak Mi'gmaq'. Also briefly introducing nige' 'now' and getu'- 'want to, going to', and the -nej 'let's...' patterns.
lesson.explnote: Mi'gmaq is a language where speakers often draw on the knowledge that they share as members of the same (or a closely related) community. For this reason, some normal ways of talking in Mi'gmaq can seem not as specific as what English speakers are used to. In Listuguj, for example, qame'g 'across (the river)' can often specifically mean Campbellton, and gm'tnigtug 'at the mountain' can often specifically mean the Sugarloaf. This way of talking is effective because speakers draw on their common understanding of where they are and which specific places would naturally tie to those words. For the same reason, it is normal and in fact more natural in Mi'gmaq to say 'speak Native' when talking about speaking the Mi'gmaq language. More specific expressions are possible, but are usually only used when really needed, say, to talk about speaking different kinds of Native languages.

line.english: Do you speak Native [lit. 'speak Native', but used where English would say 'speak Mi'gmaw']
Do you want to speak Native now?

lesson.title: Afraid to speak Native
lesson.designnote: Building on the preceding lesson, but now to address the most common problem faced by learners: embarrassment or fear of being laughed at. Also introduces 'everybody' and some basic terms for feelings; these will all be taught again in more detail in later lessons.

line.english: Do you want to speak Native now?
I'm afraid to speak Native, because I will be laughed at.
Everyone feels that way, at first.

unit.title: People, Things, "I See...", At a Location
unit.lesson:
Person Vocab
Introduces a core set of animate nouns starting from people, going through primary gender + stage of life. This is more than just simple vocabulary. These words will be the anchors for demonstrating many other patterns in later lessons, which is one reason why they are kept to this bare but still useful minimum. It is also why the introduction of these words is slow and repetitive over this and the next two lessons, which give the plural, then the singular and plural together. The images for each noun are crucial to making the set easy to learn and remember. They are given together as a single row, and if possible, it would help to highlight each image as its sound is read through. @20120723-JW-RM-1thru25.wav@5:20-5:34 [@5:20.5-5:21.5 REDO 1st]
gisigu old man S1U2/12_Mimajuinu/01-Gisigu
gisiguisgw old woman S1U2/12_Mimajuinu/02-gisiguisgw
One cultural difference that may get lost in translation is related to the two words you just learned: "gisigu" and "gisiguisgw". The English translation we give just says "old man" and "old woman", but in English both of those phrases may not seem as respectful as the Mi'gmaq words actually are. In Mi'gmaq it isn't insulting to be called "gisigu" or "gisiguisgw". These words indicate people who have fully matured and grown, who know as much as they are ever going to know. Somebody who is a "gisigu" or "gisiguisgw" is to be respected; it is not insulting to use those words (unless you are talking about somebody who is clearly not elderly).
ji'nm man S1U2/12_Mimajuinu/03-jinm
e'pit woman S1U2/12_Mimajuinu/04-epit
ji'nmji'j young man S1U2/12_Mimajuinu/05-jinmjij
e'pite's young woman S1U2/12_Mimajuinu/06-epites
lpa'tuj boy S1U2/12_Mimajuinu/07-lpatuj
e'pite'ji'j girl S1U2/12_Mimajuinu/08-epitejij
mijua'ji'j young child, baby S1U2/12_Mimajuinu/09-mijuajij
qopisun newborn S1U2/12_Mimajuinu/10-qopisun
`

lesson.title: People Vocab
lesson.designnote: Introducing the animal plural pattern through the plural forms of the preceding set of words. This may work best if the exact same pattern of introduction used for the singulars is repeated here, including the use of images described above.
lesson.explnote: To talk about more than one of a person (rather than a thing), you add the ending -g. (Sometimes, the -g needs a vowel in front of it, making it -ug or -ig.) (When it comes after a -a or a -q, the ending is always -q, never -g.) And if the ending is added to -i or -u, those sounds come out as -i' and -u', as in gisigu'g.

lesson.title: Person... ... People Vocab
lesson.designnote: This is the third of a three-part lesson set: here we repeat the singular and plural together to highlight and underline the singular vs. plural pattern. Using rows of images lined up together, singular on top of plural, is one way to reinforce this visually.

lesson.title: Thing Vocab
lesson.designnote: This lesson and the next two follow the same pattern as before, used to introduce the following words as the core set of inanimates, again as an anchor for many later lessons' material.

lesson.title: Things Vocab
lesson.designnote: Same pattern as used for animate plurals, for inanimate plurals.
lesson.explnote: To mark more than one of a thing (rather than a person), for most (but definitely not all) words the ending is -l. This comes out as -n if the word already ends in -n. This double -nn at the end of a word can be hard to hear at first, so it is a good idea to practice both saying it and listening for it. Like with people, if the ending is added to -i or -u, those sounds come out as -i' and -u', as in awti'l.

lesson.title: Thing... ...Things Vocab
lesson.designnote: Same pattern as used for animate singular vs. plural pattern, now for inanimate singular vs. plural pattern.

lesson.title: I see [a person] in the road
lesson.designnote: This begins a series of lessons that use the key idea of 'see' to introduce the four-way pattern of 'see [{animate, inanimate} {singular, plural}]'. This lesson starts with nemi'g 'I see him/her [= animate singular]'; the later ones will work through the other three possibilities. This lesson also introduces the ending -igtug, added to mark a word as a location. Armed with these three basic components (noun, verb, location), the lesson (perhaps most importantly of all) shows learners that even this early on, they can already make their own full, complete, and real-world-useful sentences. This will be a theme in the course overall. For visuals, the original singular person images are put together with the "see" image.
lesson.explnote: In this lesson we learn two new things. The word nemi'g means 'I see him/her', and can be used with any of the words for people we have learned before. The ending -igtug marks a word as a place or location, just like English words like 'in', 'on', or 'at'. Mi'gmaq has ways of showing those exact different kinds of places, but -igtug on th end of the word is usually enough. So for example, putting it on awti 'road' gets you 'in the road' or 'on the road'. Now you can make complete full sentences on your own! Mix and match the words you know, using these patterns, and try them out with speakers!

line.english: I see an old man in the road.
I see a woman in the road.
I see a boy in the road.

lesson.title: I see [people] in the road
lesson.designnote: Continuing the lesson series using 'see' to introduce the four-way pattern of 'see [{animate, inanimate} {singular, plural}]': now doing so for animate plural by bringing the original plural people images together with the "see" image.
lesson.explnote: Starting from the word nemi'g 'I see him/her', we can expand to nemi'gig 'I see them'. You can use this word with any pair or group of people. Notice that the endings sound very close to each other. This is a basic pattern of Mi'gmaq: words that are related to each other often share the same (or very similar) endings to show that relationship. Now using the words for (groups of!) people, try to mix and match again with the words you know.

line.english: I see (some) old men in the road.
I see (some) women in the road.
I see (some) boys in the road.

lesson.title: I see [a thing] in the road
lesson.designnote: Continuing the lesson series using 'see' to introduce the four-way pattern of 'see [{animate, inanimate} {singular, plural}]': now doing so for inanimate singular by bringing the original singular thing images together with the "see" image.
lesson.explnote: Before we learned the word nemi'g 'I see him/her', for talking about people. Now we learn the word nemitu 'I see it', for talking about things. Again, this is the Mi'gmaq language showing how one word is related to another. In this case, showing that 'see' is related to 'it' (since 'it' is the thing that is 'seen'). Using the words for (single!) things you have learned, try to mix and match again to make new sentences like the ones in this lesson.

line.english: I see a chair in the road.
I see a blanket in the road.
I see a rock in the road.

lesson.title: I see [things] in the road
lesson.designnote: Continuing the lesson series using 'see' to introduce the four-way pattern of 'see [{animate, inanimate} {singular, plural}]': now doing so for inanimate plural by bringing the original plural thing images together with the "see" image.
lesson.explnote: From nemitu 'I see it', we can now expand to nemituann 'I see them [things]'. You can use this word for any pair or group of things. And in fact, the extra -n on the end is the same ending you have seen in a'sunn 'blankets' and so on. Once again, Mi'gmaq is giving each word matching endings to show how they are related to each other. Again, using the words for (groups of!) things you have learned, try to mix and match again to make new sentences like the ones in this lesson.

line.english: I see (some) chairs in the road.
I see (some) blankets in the road.
I see (some) rocks in the road.

lesson.title: Consolidation [4-way chart]
lesson.designnote: 4-way chart, demonstrating the 4-way contrast in review. Again, images and text are drawn directly from the above examples to make the review explicit and help learners confirm that their understanding is correct.
lesson.explnote: In this lesson, we are just going back over the four new words/patterns you have learned: nemi'g, nemi'gig, nemitu, and nemituann.

line.english: I see an old man in the road.
I see (some) old men in the road.
I see a chair in the road.
I see (some) chairs in the road.

lesson.title: Who is that woman standing at the rock?

line.migmaq: Ji'nm nemi'g, gaqamit awtigtug. Wen na?
line.english: I see a man, standing in the road. Who is that?
That's Joseph. He's my younger brother.

line.migmaq: Wen na ala e'pite's gaqamit gun'tewigtug?
line.english: Who is that young woman standing at the rock?
That's Mary-Ann. She is my younger sister.
Who is this man in the picture?
This is my older brother. His name is Michael.

lesson.title: How many people? 1-3, many.
lesson.designnote: This lesson introduces counting (of people), using only the minimum numbers/amounts (1, 2, 3, many) needed to show the basics of the system. Image files simply show these numbers: X number of countables together, either as a natural picture or a photoshopping of X number of identical images.
lesson.explnote: In this lesson, we learn to count people: asking how many, and giving answers.

lesson.title: How many things? 1-3, many.
lesson.designnote: This lesson continues with the counting of things, again using only the minimum numbers/amounts (1, 2, 3, many) needed to show the basics of the system. Keeping the presentation identical to the preceding one should help confirm the pattern for learners. Image files again simply show these numbers: X number of countables together, either as a natural picture or a photoshopping of X number of identical images.
lesson.explnote: In this lesson, we learn to count things: asking how many, and giving answers.

lesson.title: How many people do you see?
lesson.designnote: This lesson combines the earlier nemi'g(ig)/nemitu(ann) pattern with the 'how many ...?' patterns just shown. As in earlier lessons, the main aim is helping learners see how they can now build more complex sentences. Image files again simply show these numbers: X number of countables together, either as a natural picture or a photoshopping of X number of identical images.

line.english: How many men do you see?
How many men do you see?
How many men do you see?
How many men do you see?

lesson.title: How many things do you see?
lesson.designnote: This lesson combines the earlier nemi'g(ig)/nemitu(ann) pattern with the 'how many ...?' patterns just learned, helping learners see how they can now build more complex sentences. Image files again simply show these numbers: X number of countables together, either as a natural picture or a photoshopping of X number of identical images.

line.english: How many chairs do you see?
I see one chairs in the road.
How many chairs do you see?
I see two chairs in the road.
How many chairs do you see?
I see three chairs in the road.
How many chairs do you see?

lesson.title: One, two, three...
lesson.designnote: A 10x10 chart of the numbers 1 to 100 is used here and in upcoming lessons, highlighting the number or numbers that match the sound recording. Keeping consistently to this single chart helps visually underline the patterns being learned.

lesson.title: Ten, twenty, thirty...
lesson.designnote: The 10x10 chart of the numbers 1 to 100 is used again, highlighting the number or numbers that match the sound recording. This is also the first less on to introduce pattern whereby [6, 7, 8, 9] usually cannot combine directly with a word/ending, and so use a following te's- as a stand-in.
lesson.explnote: This lesson shows how the ending -sga'q gives you 10, 20, 30 and so on. Notice that numbers 'six' through 'nine' can't combine directly with endings. Instead they use te's- after them as a stand-in. We will see this again and again in other patterns using numbers.

line.migmaq: Asugom te'sisga'q, lluigneg te'sisga'q, ugumuljin te'sisga'q, pesgunateg te'sisga'q, gasg'ptnnaqan.
line.english: Sixty, seventy, eighty, ninety, one hundred.

lesson.title: Ten plus #... Twenty plus #... Thirty plus #...
lesson.designnote: Demonstrating the use of "jel" in naming more complex numbers, we return to the 10x10 chart of the numbers 1 to 100, now highlighting the "in between" number/numbers that match the sound recording. Notice that these numbers are taught AFTER the [10, 20, 30...] progression.
lesson.explnote: The word jel basically means 'plus': so in Mi'gmaq, 'eleven' is really 'ten+one', 'twelve' is 'ten+two', and so on. Same again for 'twenty-one', and so on.

line.migmaq: Newtisga'q jel newt, newtisga'q jel ta'pu, newtisga'q jel si'st, newtisga'q jel ne'w, newtisga'q jel na'n.
Newtisga'q jel asugom, newtisga'q jel lluigneg, newtisga'q jel ugumuljin, newtisga'q jel pesgunateg.
Tapuisga'q jel newt, tapuisga'q jel si'st, tapuisga'q jel ne'w, tapuisga'q jel na'n.
Tapuisga'q jel asugom, tapuisga'q jel lluigneg, tapuisga'q jel ugumuljin, tapuisga'q jel pesgunateg.

lesson.title: One hundred, two hundred, three hundred...
lesson.designnote: Same highlighting system as above, with hundreds.
lesson.explnote: Counting hundreds is easy: you just put the numbers next to each other, and do not need to worry about special combination patterns.

line.migmaq: Gasg'ptnnaqan, ta'pu gasg'ptnnaqan, si'st gasg'ptnnaqan, ne'w gasg'ptnnaqan, na'n gasg'ptnnaqan.
line.english: One hundred, two hundred, three hundred, four hundred, five hundred

line.migmaq: Asugom gasg'ptnnaqan, lluigneg gasg'ptnnaqan, ugumuljin gasg'ptnnaqan, pesgunateg gasg'ptnnaqan, pituiptnnaqan.
line.english: Six hundred, seven hundred, eight hundred, nine hundred, one thousand

lesson.title: One thousand, two thousand, three thousand...
lesson.designnote: Same highlighting system as above, with thousands.
lesson.explnote: Counting thousands is the same as hundreds: you just put the numbers next to each other, and do not need to worry about special combination patterns.

line.migmaq: Pituiptnnaqan, ta'pu pituiptnnaqan, si'st pituiptnnaqan, ne'w pituiptnnaqan, na'n pituiptnnaqan.
line.english: One thousand, two thousand, three thousand, four thousand, five thousand

line.migmaq: Asugom pituiptnnaqan, lluigneg pituiptnnaqan, ugumuljin pituiptnnaqan, pesgunateg pituiptnnaqan, newtisga'q pituiptnnaqan.
line.english: Six thousand, seven thousand, eight thousand, nine thousand, ten thousand
